{{EngvarB|date=April 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox film awards | number = 28 | award = Bangladesh National Film Awards | image = | alt = | caption = | awarded_for = Best of Bangladeshi cinema in 2003 | award_org = [[President of Bangladesh]] | presenting_org = [[Ministry of Information (Bangladesh)|Ministry of Information]] | announced_date = | presented_date = 23 October 2008 | site = Bangladesh-China Friendship Conference Centre, [[Dhaka]], Bangladesh | host = [[Alamgir (actor)|Alamgir]] and Farzana Brownia | website ={{url|moi.gov.bd/}} | best_feature = Not Given | best_non_feature = | best_actor = [[Manna (actor)|Manna]] | best_actor_film = ''[[Bir Soinik]]'' | best_actress = [[Sadika Parvin Popy]] | best_actress_film = ''[[Karagar]]'' | most_wins = ''[[Kokhono Megh Kokhono Brishti]]'' (3) | last = 27th | next = 29th }} The '''28th National Film Awards''', presented by Ministry of Information, Bangladesh to felicitate the best of Bangladeshi Cinema released in the year 2003. Bangladesh National Film Awards is a film award ceremony in Bangladesh established in 1975 by Government of Bangladesh. Every year, a national panel appointed by the government selects the winning entry, and the award ceremony is held in Dhaka.{{cite news |author=Rashed Shaon |date= |script-title=চার দশকে আমাদের সেরা চলচ্চিত্রগুলো |trans-title=Our best films of the four-decade |url=http://glitz.bdnews24.com/details.php?catry=2&showns=2012 |work=bdnews24 |language=bn |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120820004411/http://glitz.bdnews24.com/details.php?catry=2&showns=2012 |archive-date=20 August 2012 |accessdate=4 November 2012}} Chief Adviser Dr. Fakhruddin Ahmed presented the awards at the Bangladesh-China Friendship Conference Centre on 23 October.{{cite news |author=Nadia Sarwat |title=National Film Awards generate enthusiasm |url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/newDesign/news-details.php?nid=60147 |newspaper=The Daily Star |date= |accessdate=13 October 2015}} ==List of winners== A 12-member jury board headed by Sadeq Khan, Chairman of board of directors, Press Institute of Bangladesh suggested the name of 15 artistes for the National Film Award in recognition of their outstanding contributions to the country's film industry.{{cite news |date=24 November 2004 |title=National film awards for 2002 and 2003 declared |url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/2004/11/24/d411241402105.htm |newspaper=The Daily Star |accessdate=13 October 2015}} No awards were given in Best Film, director, Music Director, Dialogue, Cinematography and Editing Categories. ===Merit Awards=== {|class="wikitable sortable collapsible" |- ! style="background:#EEDD82;"|Name of Awards ! style="background:#EEDD82;"|Winner(s) ! style="background:#EEDD82;"|Film |- |Best Actor|| [[Manna (actor)|Manna]]^ || ''[[Bir Soinik]]''{{cite news |author=Kamruzzaman |date=13 October 2009 |script-title=জাতীয় চলচ্চিত্র পুরস্কার কি আটকে যাচ্ছে? |trans-title=National Film Awards go to? |url=http://archive.prothom-alo.com/detail/news/11823 |newspaper=Prothom Alo |language=bn |accessdate=12 October 2015}} |- |Best Actress|| [[Sadika Parvin Popy]] ||''[[Karagar]]''{{cite news |script-title=নতুন বছরে নতুন উদ্যমে পপি |trans-title=Popy in the new year with renewed vigor |url=http://mediakhabor.com/?p=11137 |newspaper=Media Khabor |date= |language=bn |accessdate=31 October 2015}} |- |Best Actor in a Supporting Role|| [[Wasimul Bari Rajib]]^ & [[Sohel Rana (actor)|Sohel Rana]] ||''Sahosi Manush Chai'' |- |Best Actress in a Supporting Role|| Saathi || ''[[Bir Soinik]]'' |- |Best Actor in a Negative Role|| Kabila
Shanu || ''Ondhokar''{{cite news |author=Rahat Saiful |date=23 August 2015 |script-title=আর শোনা যাবে না কাবিলার কণ্ঠস্বর! |trans-title=But Kabila's voice will be heard! |url=http://www.risingbd.com/%E0%A6%86%E0%A6%B0-%E0%A6%B6%E0%A7%8B%E0%A6%A8%E0%A6%BE-%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%AC%E0%A7%87-%E0%A6%A8%E0%A6%BE-%E0%A6%95%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%B2%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B0-%E0%A6%95%E0%A6%A3%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%A0%E0%A6%B8%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%B0/121553 |newspaper=Risingbd |language=bn |accessdate=31 October 2015}}
''Bou Shashurir Juddho'' |- |Best Actor in a Comic Role || [[Dildar (actor)|Dildar]] || ''Tumi Shudhu Amar'' |- |Best Child Artist || Priyanka ||''[[Kokhono Megh Kokhono Brishti]]'' |- |Best Lyrics || [[Gazi Mazharul Anwar]] || ''Kokhono Megh Kokhono Brishti''{{cite web|url=http://www.bizbdnews.com/100-illustrious-and-leading-business-personalities-190 |title=Gazi Mazharul Anwar, A renowned Lyrist, Film Director & Producer |date=11 November 2011 |website=bizbdnews.com |accessdate=20 July 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150714031442/https://www.bizbdnews.com/100-illustrious-and-leading-business-personalities-190 |archivedate=14 July 2015 |df= }} |- |Best Male Playback Singer || [[Bashir Ahmad (singer)|Bashir Ahmad]] || ''Kokhono Megh Kokhono Brishti'' |- |Best Female Playback Singer || [[Baby Naznin]] || ''Sahosi Manush Chai''{{cite web|title=List of National award film |url=http://www.bfa.gov.bd/national.html |publisher=Bangladesh Film Archive |accessdate=13 October 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129203009/http://www.bfa.gov.bd/national.html |archivedate=29 November 2014 }} |} ===Technical Awards=== {|class="wikitable sortable collapsible" |- ! style="background:#EEDD82;"|Name of Awards ! style="background:#EEDD82;"|Winner(s) ! style="background:#EEDD82;"|Film |- |Best Story || [[Gias Uddin Selim]] || ''Adhiar'' |- |Best Screenplay|| Maqsudul Bari || ''Adhiar'' |- |Best Art Director|| Mohammad Kalantor ||''Dui Bodhu Ek Swami'' |} ==See also== * [[Bachsas Awards]] * [[Meril Prothom Alo Awards]] * [[Ifad Film Club Award]] * [[Babisas Award]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{Bangladesh National Film Awards}} {{National Cinema Awards}} {{DEFAULTSORT:National Film Awards (Bangladesh)}} [[Category:Cinema of Bangladesh]] [[Category:Bangladeshi awards]] [[Category:Bangladeshi media awards]] [[Category:Awards established in 1975]] [[Category:Bangladeshi film awards]]

{{Infobox comic book title | image = Alex + Ada issue 1.jpg | image_size = | alt = Alex and his new android face each other in a pose similar to a bride and groom during a wedding | caption = Issue one cover | limited = N | ongoing = N | genre = Science fiction | publisher = [[Image Comics]] | startmo = November | startyr = 2013 | endmo = June | endyr = 2015 | issues = 15 | writers = [[Jonathan Luna (comics)|Jonathan Luna]]
Sarah Vaughn | artists = Jonathan Luna | creators = Jonathan Luna
Sarah Vaughn | TPB1 = Vol 1 (#1-#5) | ISBN1 = 1632150069 | TPB2 = Vol 2 (#6-#10) | ISBN2 = 1632151952 | TPB3 = Vol 3 (#11-#15) | ISBN3 = 1632154048 | sort = Alex + Ada | nonUS = }} '''''Alex + Ada''''' is an [[American comic book]] series created by [[Jonathan Luna (comics)|Jonathan Luna]] and Sarah Vaughn. The duo began work on the series in January 2013, before publishing 15 issues through Image Comics between November 2013 and June 2015. The series has since been collected into three [[Trade paperback (comics)|trade paperbacks]]. ''Alex + Ada'' centers upon the relationship between a lonely man and an intelligent android. The series received positive reviews from critics who compared it to other popular science fiction stories, although Luna's artwork was sometimes criticized for being simplistic. ==Publication history== ===Development=== Jonathan Luna had previously created comics with his brother Joshua, but was exhausted after six straight years of work. Inspired by a [[TED (conference)|TED Talk]], he decided to take a break from working. During his two years away from comics, he painted ''[[Star Bright and the Looking Glass]]'', a fairy tale picture book that was proofread by his friend Sarah Vaughn and published in 2012.(July 30, 2012), "[https://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=40119 Jonathan Luna Goes Solo With "Star Bright and the Looking Glass"]," Comic Book Resources. Retrieved June 24, 2016 While working on the picture book, Luna realized he missed telling a story panel by panel and decided to return to comics.BigJ (November 7, 2013), "[http://bloody-disgusting.com/news/3263725/exclusive-interview-jonathan-luna-and-sarah-vaughn-reprogram-science-fiction-with-alex-ada/ Jonathan Luna and Sarah Vaughn Talk Robots & Love In ‘Alex + Ada’]," [[Bloody Disgusting]] (accessed March 12, 2016) He and his brother had decided to work on separate projects, so Luna pitched the idea of a young man who falls in love with a female android to Vaughn over dinner. Vaughn, who began writing and drawing romance comics in her youth,Dietsch, TJ (August 12, 2013), "[http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=47273 Jonathan Luna Returns To {{notatypo|Montly}} Comics With "Alex + Ada"]," [[Comic Book Resources]] (accessed March 12, 2016) jumped at the opportunity. After initializing the concept in January 2013, the two discussed the project for three or four months before creating an outline for the whole story. The original outline was for 12 issues, but it left room for improvisation and a few points were removed as the story progressed. They looked at past and present [[Civil rights movements|social movements for civil rights]] for inspiration for how one would progress and how people might respond to a movement for android rights. Luna wrote the first draft of issue one, then the two worked together to rewrite it. Luna began drawing around April. ''Alex + Ada'' is the first comic Luna drew completely [[Digital illustration|digitally.]] Because Luna needed to focus on art, Vaughn wrote the first draft of the remaining issues. She and Luna would discuss the draft, then she would rewrite it. ===Publication=== The first issue of ''Alex + Ada'' was released November 6, 2013,(November 7, 2013), "[http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=user_review&id=6628 Review: Alex + Ada #1]," Comic Book Resources (accessed April 1, 2016) and was Vaughn's first published comic work. It was the 141st best selling issue of the month with estimated sales around 15,000,"[https://www.comichron.com/monthlycomicssales/2013/2013-11.html Comic Book Sales Figures for November 2013]," [[Comichron]] (accessed April 1, 2016) which was more than any book Luna had done previously. During the course of publication, the series length was increased from 12 issues to 15 issues. Each issue was released approximately six weeks apart, with the final issue available June 18, 2015."[https://imagecomics.com/comics/release-archive/series/alex-ada Alex + Ada Series Release Archive]," Image Comics (accessed April 1, 2016) Issue 15 was the 206th best selling issue of the month with estimated orders around 8,250."[https://www.comichron.com/monthlycomicssales/2015/2015-06.html Comic Book Sales Figures for June 2015]," Comichron (accessed April 1, 2016) The series has been collected into three [[Trade paperback (comics)|trade paperbacks]], each containing five issues."[https://imagecomics.com/comics/series/alex-ada Alex + Ada]," Image Comics. retrieved June 24, 2016 ==Plot== Alex is a young man who is depressed after his fiancée breaks up with him. Tired of seeing him unhappy, Alex's grandmother sends him Ada, a Tanaka X-5 android which is capable of intelligent human interaction. The robot is initially incapable of self-awareness, as each android has a program that blocks any potential free thought or consciousness. Alex decides to remove this program and grant Ada her own mental freedom, as he is uninterested in a partner who cannot truly interact with him. Because removing the program is illegal and carries harsh consequences for both Ada and Alex, they have to pretend Ada is not self-aware. When a jealous love-interest of Alex reports Ada as sentient to the FBI, Alex and Ada attempt to flee the country. When they are intercepted by the FBI, Ada gets shot by the police and Alex is arrested. He is convicted and sentenced to 25 years in prison, but Ada is not found to be sentient. During his time in prison, rights are granted to sentient robots. On Alex's release, Ada is returned to him. She appears to be non-sentient, but Alex discovers she locked her consciousness to protect him. He restores her freedom and is re-united with her. ==Reception== According to [[review aggregator]] Comic Book Round Up, critics gave the first issue an average 8.0/10based on 21 reviews, "[http://comicbookroundup.com/comic-books/reviews/image-comics/alex-+-ada/1 Alex + Ada #1 on Comic Book Round Up]," Comic Book Round Up (accessed March 12, 2016) and the series as a whole 8.5/10.based on 134 reviews, "[http://comicbookroundup.com/comic-books/reviews/image-comics/alex-+-ada Alex + Ada on Comic Book Round Up]," Comic Book Round Up (accessed March 12, 2016) During its publication, ''Alex + Ada'' appeared on many "best of" lists created by comic news websites. *O'Neil, Tim and Sava, Oliver (December 9, 2014), "[http://www.avclub.com/article/best-comics-2014-ongoing-and-special-series-212601 The best comics of 2014: Ongoing and special series]," [[The A.V. Club]] (accessed March 12, 2016) *Simons, Kyle (February 5, 2015), "[http://www.popmythology.com/best-comics-of-2014/ The Best Comics of 2014]," Pop Mythology (accessed March 12, 2015) *CBR New Team (December 29, 2014), "[http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=58047 CBR's top 100 comics of 2014: #75-51]," Comic Book Resources (accessed March 12, 2016) *Deadshirt Staff (December 15, 2014), "[http://deadshirt.net/2014/12/15/deadshirts-top-ten-comics-2014/ Deadshirt's Top Ten Comics of 2014]," Deadshirt (accessed March 12, 2016) *(December 15, 2014), "[http://www.grayhavencomics.com/2014/12/15/best-of-2014/ Best of 2014]," Grayhaven Comics (accessed March 12, 2015) *Long, Aaron (December 30, 2014), "[http://www.comicosity.com/best-of-2014-best-series/ Best of 2014: Best Series]," Comicosity (accessed March 12, 2016) *Rodriguez, Peter (January 15, 2015), "[http://geeksushi.com/best-ongoing-comics-of-2014/ Best Ongoing Comics of 2014]," Geek Sushi (accessed March 12, 2016) *Multiversity Staff (December 19, 2014), "[http://www.multiversitycomics.com/news-columns/2014-in-review-best-ongoing-series/ 2014 in Review: Best Ongoing Series]," [[Multiversity Comics]] (accessed March 12, 2016) Reviewing for [[Bleeding Cool]], Zac Thompson and David Dissanayake made favorable comparisons to the 1982 film ''[[Blade Runner]]'' and the 2013 film ''[[Her (film)|Her]]''.{{cite web|last1=Thompson|first1=Zac|title=Review: "Alex + Ada" #7|url=http://bloody-disgusting.com/reviews/3299456/review-alex-ada-7/|publisher=Bloody Disgusting|accessdate=20 December 2014}}{{cite web|last1=Dissanayake|first1=David|title=Image Watch: On Alex+Ada Being The Most Underrated Series Being Published|url=http://www.bleedingcool.com/2014/06/12/image-watch-on-alexada-being-the-most-underrated-series-being-published/|publisher=Bleeding Cool|accessdate=20 December 2014}} Dissanayake also noted the entertaining realism, as it "feels like our world, full of technologies that...will [exist] very soon." [[Comic Book Resources]]' Sonia Harris also praised the series for its realism, writing the "metaphor of artificially intelligent beings living out their secret lives, unsafe and insecure, yet potentially stronger and smarter than humans is potent."{{cite web|last1=Harris|first1=Sonia|title=Committed: The Unfolding Layers of Alex + Ada|url=http://goodcomics.comicbookresources.com/2014/10/22/committed-the-unfolding-layers-of-alex-ada/|publisher=Comic Book Resources|accessdate=20 December 2014}} Dean Stell, a reviewer for [[Weekly Comic Book Review]], said Luna and Vaughn created "a wonderful and classically-themed science-fiction story."Stell, Dean (November 7, 2013), "[http://weeklycomicbookreview.com/2013/11/07/alex-ada-1-review/ Alex + Ada #1 Review]," Weekly Comic Book Review (accessed March 12, 2016) Writing for [[Bloody Disgusting]], Lonnie Nadler said Luna's work on facial expressions was the "major highlight" of his illustrations.Nadler, Lonnie (November 8, 2013), "[http://bloody-disgusting.com/news/3264107/review-alex-ada-1/ Review: Alex + Ada #1]," Bloody Disgusting (accessed March 12, 2015) Luna's simplistic artwork is a frequent point of criticism among reviewers,Pepose, David (November 5, 2013), "[http://www.newsarama.com/19486-best-shots-advance-reviews-trio-of-image-first-issues-umbral-drumhellar-alex-ada.html Best Shots Advance Reviews: Trio of Image First Issues: Umbral, Drumhellar, Alex & Ada]," [[Newsarama]] (accessed March 12, 2015){{cite web|last1=Grey|first1=Melissa|title=Alex + Ada #1 Review|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2013/11/07/alex-ada-1-review|publisher=[[IGN]]|accessdate=20 December 2014}} although some call it appropriate for the setting.Reese, Nathan (December 17, 2014), "[http://www.complex.com/pop-culture/2014/12/sarah-vaughn-and-jonathan-luna-interview/ Dystopian Dream Girl: Sarah Vaughn and Jonathan Luna Talk Their Android Love Story, "Alex + Ada"]," Complex (accessed March 12, 2016)Harper, David (June 25, 2015), "[http://sktchd.com/interview/jonathan-luna-and-sarah-vaughn-talk-the-star-crossed-lovers-of-alex-ada/ Luna and Vaughn Talk the Star Crossed Lovers of Alex + Ada]," SKTCHD (accessed March 12, 2016){{cite web|last=Thompson|first=Kelly|author-link=Kelly Thompson|title=Alex + Ada #1 (review)|url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=user_review&id=6628|publisher=Comic Book Resources|accessdate=20 December 2014}} In addition to Luna's "painfully plain" illustrations, [[Newsarama]]'s David Pepose also criticized the story's pace. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Good article}} ==External links== * {{officialwebsite|https://imagecomics.com/comics/series/alex-ada}} {{Luna Brothers}} [[Category:2013 comics debuts]] [[Category:Science fiction comics]]

{{good article}} An '''ashcan copy''' is a type of [[American comic book]] publication created solely to establish trademarks on potential titles and not intended for sale, which was done in the 1930s and 1940s when the comic book industry was in its infancy. The term was revived in the 1980s by [[Bob Burden]], who used the term for prototypes of his self-published comic book. Since the 1990s, it has been used to describe promotional materials produced in large [[print run]]s and made available for mass consumption. In the film and television industries, the term has been adopted for low-grade material created to preserve a claim to licensed property rights.
==Original use== In the 1930s, the modern comic book was created and rapidly grew in popularity.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://the-artifice.com/history-of-comics/ |title=The History of Comics: Decade by decade |last=Ramsey |first=Taylor |date=February 5, 2013 |website=The Artifice |publisher= |access-date=June 23, 2018 }}</ref> In the competition to secure [[trademark]]s on titles intended to sound thrilling, publishers like [[All-American Publications]] and [[Fawcett Comics]] developed the ashcan edition,<ref name="Wiz30">{{cite magazine |last1=Christensen |first1=William A |last2=Seifert |first2=Mark |date=February 1994 |title=Evolution of the Ashcan |magazine=[[Wizard (magazine)|Wizard]] #30 |location=[[New York City]] |publisher=[[Wizard Entertainment]] |page=89 }}</ref> which was the same size as regular comics and usually had a black and white cover.<ref name="Wiz30"/> Typically, cover art was recycled from previous publications with a new title pasted to it.<ref name="BC">{{cite web |url=https://www.bleedingcool.com/2014/08/01/75-years-ago-today-dc-comics-wins-the-race-for-flash/ |title=75 Years Ago Today: DC Comics Wins The Race For Flash |last=Seifert |first=Mark |date=August 1, 2014 |website=[[Bleeding Cool]] |publisher=[[Avatar Press]] |access-date=June 19, 2018 }}</ref> Interior artwork ranged from previously published material in full color<ref name="Wiz30"/><ref name="BC"/> to unfinished [[Penciller|pencils]] without [[word balloon]]s.<ref name="MW">{{cite web |url=https://www.marketwatch.com/story/why-these-comic-books-still-sell-for-millions-of-dollars-2017-10-07 |title=As fans throng to New York Comic Con, these comic books sell for millions of dollars |last=Malito |first=Alessandra |date=October 9, 2017 |website=[[MarketWatch]] |access-date=December 11, 2017 }}</ref> Not all of the titles secured through ashcan editions were actually used for regular publications.<ref name="FCA">{{cite book |last1=Hamerlinck |first1=Paul |first2=Ralph |last2=Daigh |date= |title=Fawcett Companion: The Best of FCA |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=E8z-CaR1OdcC&pg=PA107&dq=comic+ashcan&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjtyondn4HcAhUmrlkKHX3CBicQ6AEITTAH#v=onepage&q=comic%20ashcan&f=false |location= |publisher= |page=107 |isbn= }}</ref>
The purpose of the ashcan editions was to fool the [[US Patent & Trademark Office]] into believing the book had actually been published.<ref name="Hero"/> Clerks at the office would accept the hastily produced material as legitimate, granting the submitting publisher a trademark to the title.<ref name="CGC"/> Since the ashcans had no other use, publishers printed as few as two copies; one was [[legal deposit|sent to]] the Trademark Office, the other was kept for their files.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2011-08-13/news/ct-talk-comics-display-20110813_1_comic-books-moondog-chain-gareb-shamus |title=Rare 'ashcan' comic books on display at Chicago Comic Con |last=Cox |first=Brian L |date=August 13, 2011 |website=[[Chicago Tribune]] |publisher= |access-date=December 11, 2017}}</ref> Occasionally, publishers would send copies to [[Wholesaling|distributors or wholesalers]] by [[registered mail]] to further establish publication dates,<ref name="BC"/> but nearly all ashcan comic editions were limited to five copies or less.<ref name="Wiz30"/>
After being accepted by the Trademark Office, the ashcans were meant to be thrown away.<ref name="Hero"/> At the time, [[waste container]]s were commonly called "ash cans" because they were used to hold soot and ash from wood and coal heating systems. The term was applied to these editions of comics because they had no value.<ref name="MW"/> However, some spare copies were given to editors and other employees to keep as souvenirs.<ref name="Hero"/> The practice of creating and submitting ashcans was abandoned when publishers began to consider it an unnecessary effort that was used by lawyers to justify a fee.<ref name="FCA"/> Because of their rarity, ashcans from this era are desired by collectors and often fetch a high price.<ref name="MW"/>
==Later use== In the 1980s, [[Bob Burden]] was a dealer and collector of [[Golden Age of comic books|Golden Age]] comic books who was aware of ashcan comics.<ref name="Hero"/><ref name="Wiz30"/> He was also the creator of a comic character, Flaming Carrot, who starred in ''[[Flaming Carrot Comics]]'' published by [[Aardvark-Vanaheim]] beginning in 1984.<ref name="DAK40">{{cite news | first = Jack | last = Mallette | date = November 1986 | title = Bob Burden (part 1) | work = [[Comics Interview]] | issue = 40 | pages = 22–41 | publisher = [[Fictioneer Books]]}}</ref> For each issue, Burden had magazine-sized prototype editions printed and shared them with friends and people who assisted with production.<ref name="Wiz30"/> Some were also sent to retailers as advance previews to generate interest in his comic.<ref name="Hero"/> Fewer than 40 copies of each prototype were made, and Burden described them as ashcans.<ref name="Wiz30"/>
In 1992, [[Rob Liefeld]] applied the term to two [[Digest size|digest-sized]] prototype versions of ''[[Youngblood (comics)|Youngblood]]'' #1, but this ashcan was created for mass release. Instead of denoting the material as worthless, Liefeld's usage implied rarity and collectability.<ref name="Wiz30"/> This ashcan was the first publication from [[Image Comics]], a new publisher started by popular artists during a [[Comic book collecting#The speculator boom|boom period for comic books]]. The sales success of the ''Youngblood'' ashcans prompted imitation, and for the next year nearly every new Image series had a corresponding ashcan.<ref name="Hero">{{cite magazine |last=Colabuono |first=Gary |date=July 1993 |title=Ashcan Comics |magazine=[[Hero Illustrated]] #1 |location=[[Lombard, Illinois]] |publisher=[[Warrior Publications]] |page=56 }}</ref> The typical print run for Image ashcans was between 500 and 5,000. Soon, other publishers began using the idea in a variety of sizes and formats.<ref name="Wiz30"/> In 1993, [[Triumphant Comics]] advertised ashcan editions of new properties with print runs of 50,000.<ref>{{cite magazine |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Advertisement |magazine=[[Hero Illustrated]] #2|page=125 |location=[[Lombard, Illinois]] |publisher=[[Warrior Publications]] |date= August 1993 }}</ref>
Following the collapse of the [[speculation]] market in comics in the mid-1990s, the term has been used for promotional books.<ref name="CGC">{{cite web |url=https://www.cgccomics.com/news/viewarticle.aspx?IDArticle=2587&historic-dc-ashcan-comic-books-in-heritage-new-york-auction |title=Historic DC Ashcan Comic Books in Heritage New York Auction |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=January 31, 2012 |website=[[Comics Guaranty|CGC Comics]] |access-date= June 19, 2018}}</ref> Established publishers such as [[Dark Horse Comics]], [[IDW Publishing]], and [[DC Comics]] continue to use ashcan copies as part of their marketing plan for new titles.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cbr.com/c2e2-bobby-curnow-unleashes-battle-beasts-at-idw/ |title=C2E2: Bobby Curnow Unleashes "Battle Beasts" at IDW |last= |first= |date=April 12, 2012 |website=[[Comic Book Resources]] |access-date=July 2, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bleedingcool.com/2017/04/20/lets-read-dark-mattermaster-class-ashcan-dc-comics-together-shall/ |title=Let's All Read The Dark Matter/Master Class Ashcan From DC Comics |author=<!--Not stated--> |date= |website=[[Bleeding Cool]] |publisher=[[Avatar Press]] |access-date= July 2, 2018}}</ref><ref name="DH">{{cite web |url=https://www.bleedingcool.com/2015/03/12/dark-horse-sends-fight-club-2-rebels-archie-vs-predator-ashcans/ |title=Dark Horse Sends Fight Club 2, Rebels And Archie Vs. Predator |last= |first= |date=March 12, 2015 |website=[[Bleeding Cool]] |publisher=[[Avatar Press]] |access-date=June 25, 2018}}</ref> Aspiring creators also apply the term to [[minicomic|hand-stapled photocopied books]] they use to demonstrate their abilities to hiring editors at [[comic book convention]]s or as part of a submissions package.<ref>{{cite book |last=Hart |first=Christopher |date=2014 |title=Drawing Cutting Edge Anatomy |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=88dnAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT265&lpg=PT265&dq=ashcan+comic+sales&source=bl&ots=_P3MHHEy0E&sig=qENx5uRjn3sgURottNXQHX1LArM&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiLgpCZzYLYAhWDDxoKHZVVBXwQ6AEIXDAJ#v=snippet&q=ashcan&f=false |location= |publisher=Potter/Ten Speed/Harmony/Rodale |page= |isbn=9780770434861 }}</ref>
==Film and television== The term has been appropriated by the film and television industries to refer to low-quality material made specifically to preserve rights to a [[License#Artwork and character licensing|licensed character]], which often expire if unused for a set period of time. One of the earliest examples of this practice is the 1966 animated adaptation of ''[[Adaptations of The Hobbit#Film and television|The Hobbit]]''.<ref name="MF">{{cite web |url=http://mentalfloss.com/article/62203/weird-history-ashcan-copy |title=The Weird History of the "Ashcan Copy" |last=Wirestone |first=Clay |date=March 13, 2015 |website=[[Mental Floss]] |access-date=June 19, 2018}}</ref> Other prominent examples include ''[[Hellraiser: Revelations]]'',<ref name="Bloody-Disgusting.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/23861 |title=BD Horror News – BD Review: First Ever 'Hellraiser: Revelations' Review! |publisher=Bloody-Disgusting.com |accessdate=September 2, 2011}}</ref> a 2015 adaptation of ''[[The Wheel of Time#Television and film|The Wheel of Time]]'',<ref name="MF"/> and the [[The Fantastic Four (unreleased film)|unreleased Fantastic Four film]] from 1994.<ref name=itop109>{{cite news | title = Fantastic Faux! | first = Robert | last = Ito | work = [[Los Angeles (magazine)|Los Angeles]] | date = March 2005 | page = 108 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SF8EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA108&dq=%22lee+is+talking+about+a+far+different+movie%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=JrLjUKTbDoqH0QHVpoCQDg&ved=0CDoQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22lee%20is%20talking%20about%20a%20far%20different%20movie%22&f=false | accessdate = January 1, 2012}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9)
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=June 2015}} {{multiple issues|
{{one source|date=February 2015}} {{unreliable sources|date=February 2015}} {{update|date=February 2015}} {{more footnotes|date=February 2015}} }} {{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = Australian Classification Review Board |formed = 1970 |dissolved = |jurisdiction = [[Australia|Commonwealth of Australia]] |superseding = |minister1_name = [[George Brandis]] |minister1_pfo = [[Attorney general|Attorney-General]] |parent_agency = [[Attorney-General's Department (Australia)|Attorney-General's Department]] (current parent agency), OFLC (original parent agency), [[Australian Classification Board]] (brother agency) |website = http://www.classification.gov.au }} The '''Australian Classification Review Board''' is a [[Statute|statutory]] [[censorship]] and classification body overseen by the [[Government of Australia|Australian Government]]. The corporate body is responsible for reviewing classification decisions made by the [[Australian Classification Board]] concerning [[film]]s, [[video game]]s and [[publication]]s for exhibition, sale or hire in [[Australia]]. Review decisions need to be initiated by an appeal from a previous applicant, most commonly referred to as "aggrieved party", or a Federal or State Attorney-General.
==Organizations== The Classification Review Board is a statutory body established by the [http://www.comlaw.gov.au/comlaw%5Cmanagement.nsf/lookupindexpagesbyid/IP200401401?OpenDocument Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Act 1995 (Cth)]. This Act also provides a basis for the [http://www.comlaw.gov.au/comlaw/management.nsf/lookupindexpagesbyid/IP200508203?OpenDocument National Classification Code] which guides their decision making. As the State and Territory governments retain responsibility for enforcing censorship and could withdraw from, or ignore the national classification scheme if they so wished, any changes to the national classification scheme must be agreed to by all the State and Territory Censorship Ministers (usually Attorneys-General). South Australia is the only state to maintain a separate [https://web.archive.org/web/20100705122212/http://www.agd.sa.gov.au/about_us/saclass_council.php Classification Council] which can override national classification decisions applicable within the state.
The Classification Review Board does not censor material by ordering cuts or changes. However, they are able to effectively censor media by refusing classification and making the media illegal for hire, exhibit and import to Australia.
==Classification decisions== There have been various films and video games that have appealed the ratings as set by the Australian Classification board. Appeals include:
===2017=== *'''''[[Jigsaw (2017 film)|Jigsaw]]''''' – [[StudioCanal]] successfully lowered the film's rating from R18+ to MA15+. The main reason being that the most graphic images were dimly lit and only fleetingly seen. *'''''[[Split (2017 film)|Split]]''''' – ''Consumers of Mental Health WA'' failed to appeal the film's M rating for an MA15+ because the content and complex mental illness theme was judged to be only moderate in impact and justified by context. ===2012=== *'''''[[Prometheus (2012 film)|Prometheus]]''''' – Originally classified MA15+ for strong sci-fi violence specifically the birth scene, it was later downgraded to an M classification due to said scene being mitigated by a medical context. ===2011=== <ref>http://www.classification.gov.au/www/cob/classification.nsf/Page/InformationCentre_MediaReleases_2011MediaReleases</ref> *'''''[[The House of the Dead: Overkill|The House of the Dead: Overkill – Extended Cut]]''''' – Sega successfully appealed its rating for an MA15+ on the basis that the over-the-top violence mitigated the impact. *'''''[[We Dare]]''''' – Federal Attorney-General [[Brendan O'Connor (politician)|Brendan O'Connor]] failed to appeal the game's rating and thus stuck with its PG rating on the basis that the sexual references were only mild in impact. *'''''[[Mortal Kombat (2011 video game)|Mortal Kombat]]''''' – Warner Bros. failed its appeal to attain an MA15+ rating due to violence being of a high degree; due to a lack of an R18+ at the time, the game was subsequently refused classification for a second time. Has since been re-rated R18+ uncut after said rating's introduction. *'''''[[The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn - Part 1]]''''' Originally received an MA15+ classification due to the strong themes involving an intense birth scene. It was later downgraded to an M rating due to the fantasy nature of the themes.
===2010=== <ref>http://www.classification.gov.au/www/cob/classification.nsf/Page/ClassificationinAustralia_Whoweare_ClassificationReviewBoardDecisions_reviewBoarddecisions-2010</ref> *'''''[[The Karate Kid (2010 film)|The Karate Kid]]''''' – Lowered its M rating to a PG due to the consensus being that the violence was not detailed and was relatively infrequent within the narrative. *'''''[[Salò, or the 120 Days of Sodom|Salo]]''''' – Federal Attorney-General Brendan O'Conner tried to appeal its R18+ rating. It was originally banned since 1997 but was recently re-rated by the classification board. The film was again awarded an R18+ rating due to the additional three hours of extras which give context to the film, the same reason as the classification board.
===2009=== <ref>http://www.classification.gov.au/www/cob/classification.nsf/Page/ClassificationinAustralia_Whoweare_ClassificationReviewBoardDecisions_ReviewBoarddecisions-2009</ref> *'''''[[Alien vs Predator]]''''' – Appealed its RC rating and won, attaining an MA15+. The reason they deemed it as suitable for 15-year-olds is its science fiction context and how the mutilations were randomly generated and the player had no control over it. *'''''[[Charlie Wilson's War (film)|Charlie Wilson's War]]''''' – Bob Debus, the Minister for Home Affairs at the time, appealed the M rating of the film as he thought the nudity should have given the film a higher and restricted MA15+. He failed and the film retained the same rating of M, though with the added consumer advice of 'partial nudity'. *'''''[[Friday the 13th (2009 film)|Friday the 13th (2009 remake)]]''''' – Appealed its R18+ rating but lost due to how the violence frequently dwells on detail. *'''Hydrolord the Game''' (board game) – Bob Debus, the Minister for Home Affairs at the time, tried to appeal the M rating of this board game to cause it to receive a restricted rating of 'Category 1 18+' due to drug references, the board found that the drug references were very discreet thus awarding it the same rating of M. *'''''[[Julie & Julia]]''''' – Appealed its M rating and won in which it was re-rated PG for 'Infrequent coarse language'. It won the appeal as the word "fuck" was used briefly and can easily be missed and is used in context to calm another character down. *'''''[[Left 4 Dead 2]]''''' – Appealed its RC rating but lost. This was due to the relentlessly graphic and detailed depictions of violence and gore throughout the game and thus could not be accommodated at the MA15+ rating. The game later received an R18+ classification. *'''''[[The Loved Ones (film)|The Loved Ones]]''''' – Appealed its R18+ and won, it was then re-rated MA15+. This was due to that the most violent scenes generally had a dark comedic overtone to it thus reducing the impact. *'''''[[Stone Bros.]]''''' – Appealed its MA15+ but failed. This was due to how, despite the film showing negative effects on drugs, there are certain scenes explicitly detailing how to actually form them.
===2008=== <ref>http://www.classification.gov.au/www/cob/classification.nsf/Page/ClassificationinAustralia_Whoweare_ClassificationReviewBoardDecisions_Boarddecisions-2008</ref> *'''''[[F.E.A.R. 2]]''''' – Appealed its RC rating and was awarded with a MA15+. The board found that the violence was expected in its genre and the most violent events occurred without player control. *'''''[[Open Season 2]]''''' – Appealed its PG rating but failed as the violence was a bit too intense for younger viewers. *'''''[[Space Chimps]]''''' – Successfully appealed its PG rating and won its G rating as the comedic overtone lessened the impact to young children.
===2007=== <ref>http://www.classification.gov.au/www/cob/classification.nsf/Page/ClassificationinAustralia_Whoweare_ClassificationReviewBoardDecisions_ReviewBoardDecisions-2007</ref> *'''''[[300 (film)|300]]''''' – Won its appeal and its R18+ was downgraded to a MA15+ due to how unrealistic the CGI effects were causing all the violence to be highly stylized. *'''''[[30 days of night (film)|30 Days of Night]]''''' – Won its appeal and was awarded an MA15+ rating over its previous R18+. The reason was that it took place in a clear fantasy environment and that the vampires bled black blood lessening the impact. *'''''[[Notes on a Scandal (film)|Notes on a Scandal]]''''' – Lost its appeal and stayed with its MA15+ rating due to how sensitive the public is to sex with a minor even with the film's implied sex scenes. *'''''[[Sleuth (2007 film)|Sleuth]]''''' (remake) – Successfully appealed its MA15+ rating for an M rating. The board found that the two uses of 'cunt' was, while aggressive, still infrequent. *'''''[[Saw IV]]''''' – Was originally rated R18+ due to the violent/sadistic content and graphic bloodshed. It was decreased to MA15+ based on the content being similar to the previous installments, which were rated MA15+. The notable scenes were the eye gouging, autopsy scene, hair scalping scene and hammer bashing scenes. *[[Sea Patrol (season 1)|'''''Sea Patrol'' (season 1)''']] – Lost its appeal and stayed with its M rating due to certain scenes dwelling on detail of blood.
===2006=== <ref>http://www.classification.gov.au/www/cob/classification.nsf/Page/ClassificationinAustralia_Whoweare_ClassificationReviewBoardDecisions_ReviewBoarddecisions-2006</ref> *'''''[[Marc Ecko's Getting Up: Contents Under Pressure]]''''' – Federal Attorney-General Phil Ruddock applied to appeal the MA15+ of the rating to force into the RC (banned) territory. He succeeded and banned the game as the board noted that while all the violence, coarse language and drug references may be accommodated within the MA15+ category, the theme proved to be high impact due to the glorification of graffiti. *'''''[[Eragon (film)|Eragon]]''''' – Lost its appeal of the M rating due to violence being too frequent to fit within the PG classification. *'''''[[Stormbreaker (film)|Stormbreaker]]''''' – As with ''Eragon'', lost its appeal of the M rating due to the frequency of the violence. *'''''[[River Queen]]''''' – Won its appeal for lowering its MA15+ rating for an M rating. This was due to the historical context of the film mitigating the impact. *'''''[[Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire]]''''' – Lost its appeal due to the dark nature of the film being deemed too impactful to fit into the PG category. *'''''[[Big Momma's House 2]]''''' – Won its appeal to lower its M rating into a PG rating. This was due to the overall comedic tone lessening the impact of the violence.
All appeals before 2006 were done when the review board was not owned by the Attorney-general's department but instead when it was overlooked by the Office of Film and Literature Classification (OFLC).
===2005=== <ref>http://www.classification.gov.au/www/cob/classification.nsf/Page/ClassificationinAustralia_Whoweare_ClassificationReviewBoardDecisions_ReviewBoarddecisions-2005</ref> *'''''[[50 Cent Bulletproof]]''''' – Lost its appeal to drop its RC banning due to the frequent detailed violence. *'''''[[A History of Violence]]''''' – Won its appeal for a MA15+ rating as while the violence was very detailed and realistic, it was infrequent within the film. *'''''[[Mysterious Skin]]''''' – Attorney-general Phil Ruddock once again tried to get another film banned. He failed due to how the film does not glorify sexual abuse of children. *'''''[[Kingdom of Heaven (film)|Kingdom of Heaven]]''''' – Won its appeal for an M rating due to the historical context of the film mitigating the impact. *'''''[[Wolf Creek (film)|Wolf Creek]]''''' – Lost its appeal and stayed as an R18+ due to how realistic and frequent the violence is. *'''''[[Wedding Crashers]]''''' – Was awarded a downgrade to an M rating due to the sexual references being while frequent, only moderate in impact. *'''''[[Constantine (film)|Constantine]]''''' – Was awarded an M rating, down from its MA15+ due to how the violence was generally undetailed and stylized. *'''''[[Guess Who (film)|Guess Who]]''''' – Lost its appeal and stayed with its M rating due to how frequent the sexual references are. *'''''[[9 Songs]]''''' – Won its appeal for an R18+, it was originally given an X18+ but due to a technicality in the guidelines of how even fetishes are not allowed in the X18+ category, something which the classification board overlooked, they awarded it an R18+ based upon artistic merit. *'''''[[Fantastic Four (2005 film)|Fantastic Four]]''''' – Won its appeal for a PG rating due to how highly stylized the violence was.
===2002=== <ref>http://www.classification.gov.au/www/cob/classification.nsf/Page/ClassificationinAustralia_Whoweare_ClassificationReviewBoardDecisions_ReviewBoarddecisions-2002</ref> *'''''[[Spirit: Stallion of the Cimarron]]''''' – Won its appeal for a G rating due to there being a low sense of threat for children. *'''''[[Baise-Moi]]''''' – The General-attorney succeeded in appealing its R18+ rating. However, The film was subsequently rated Refused Classification (banned) on 10 May 2002 by the classification board due to "very high impact sexual violence throughout" which resulted in the film being banned Australia wide since then. *'''''[[Australian Rules]]''''' – Awarded an M rating due to the drug use, violence, and course language being justified by its context and message, thus the film was only moderate in impact. *'''''[[E.T. the Extra Terrestrial]]''''': ''20th Anniversary Edition'' – Failed to lower its PG rating due to there being certain scenes that may be distressful for young children. *'''''[[Black Hawk Down (film)|Black Hawk Down]]''''' – Was originally rated R18+ due to its graphic and relentless violence and a detailed scene of war injury/surgery later on it was appealed and it awarded an MA15+ on the basis that the graphic war violence was justified by its strong anti-war message.
===2000=== <ref>http://www.classification.gov.au/www/cob/classification.nsf/Page/ClassificationinAustralia_Whoweare_ClassificationReviewBoardDecisions_ReviewBoarddecisions-2000</ref> *'''''[[The Monkey's Mask]]''''' – Lost its appeal to drop the R18+ due to the theme of fetishes not being treated discreetly enough to warrant an MA15+ *'''''[[Almost Famous]]''''' – Dropped its MA15+ to an M due to how the drug use was not exploitively used in its depiction and shows its negative sides *'''''[[The Color of Paradise]]''''' – Successfully appealed its M to the PG rating. This was due to that the themes depicted are mitigated by their complicities for young children to understand.
===1999=== <ref>http://www.classification.gov.au/www/cob/rwpattach.nsf/VAP/(084A3429FD57AC0744737F8EA134BACB)~227+-+Annual+Report+-+1999+-+2000.pdf/$file/227+-+Annual+Report+-+1999+-+2000.pdf</ref> *'''''[[The Blair Witch Project]]''''' – Won its appeal to lower its MA15+ to M as while there were instances of aggressive strong language, they were limited to only two scenes and thus infrequent within the narrative *'''''[[Eyes Wide Shut]]''''' – Lost the appeal and stuck with its R18+, as the sex scenes were too realistic rather than implied/discreet to fit into the MA15+ rating *'''''[[Fight Club (film)|Fight Club]]''''' – Lost appeal for the MA15+ rating as it had adult themes of a high degree of intensity that were not discreet *'''''[[The General's Daughter (film)|The General's Daughter]]''''' – Won its appeal and lowered rating to MA15+ as the theme of rape was not high impact and the rape scene was more suggestive then graphic. *'''''[[The Iron Giant]]''''' – Lost the appeal and stayed a PG due to several scenes being too intense for young children *'''''[[Human Traffic]]''''' – Lost appeal for MA15+ due to its promotion of drugs as an escapism *'''''[[Romance (1999 film)|Romance]]''''' – Won its appeal to unban the film and rerated R18+ due to its serious intent and artistic merit despite explicit sex *'''''[[Tarzan (1999 film)|Tarzan]]''''' – Lost appeal to lower PG rating due to several menacing themes that could not be accommodated at the G rating *'''''[[Madness (1999 film)|Madness]]''''' – Lost its appeal to lowers its RC rating due to explicit sexual violence
===1998=== <ref>http://www.classification.gov.au/www/cob/rwpattach.nsf/VAP/(084A3429FD57AC0744737F8EA134BACB)~182+-+Annual+Report+98-99.pdf/$file/182+-+Annual+Report+98-99.pdf</ref> *'''''[[Analyze This]]''''' – Lost its appeal to lower its MA15+ as it contained constant coarse language that were too aggressive to be in fit into the M rating. It was later re-rated M in 2003, and again in 2006. *'''''[[Saving Private Ryan]]''''' – Won appeal to be rated MA15+ as despite having intense, prolonged graphic scenes of violence, they were non-gratuitous, infrequent and contained a strong anti-war message *'''''[[Passion (1998 film)|Passion]]''''' – Appeal failed as the pervasive theme of sado-masochistic behaviour could not fit into the MA15+ category *'''''[[Hurrah (film)|Hurrah]]''''' – Won the MA15+ rating as the noted sex scene was while somewhat graphic, was shown in a series of shots mitigating its impact
===1997=== <ref>http://www.classification.gov.au/www/cob/rwpattach.nsf/VAP/(084A3429FD57AC0744737F8EA134BACB)~183+-+Annual+Report+97-98.pdf/$file/183+-+Annual+Report+97-98.pdf</ref>
*'''''[[Anastasia (1997 film)|Anastasia]]''''' – Appeal for a G rating failed due to the various scenes that were found to upset small children *'''''[[Men in Black (1997 film)|Men in Black]]''''' – Appeal failed as the violence was too frequent to be accommodated within the PG rating *'''''[[FairyTale: A True Story]]''''' – Won its appeal for a G rating as the themes were discreetly used to avoid distressing younger children *'''''[[The Devil's Advocate (1997 film)|The Devil's Advocate]]''''' – Lost its appeal for a MA15+ as the board noted that the sex and violence were gratuitously detailed and/or prolonged. In 2012 the film was re-rated MA15+ on Blu-ray. *'''''[[Primary Colors (film)|Primary Colors]]''''' – Won its appeal to lower its MA15+ to an M rating as the frequent use of "fuck" was not gratuitous and contextually justified *'''''[[Salò, or the 120 Days of Sodom]]''''' – The Attorney general at the time appealed to ban the film (originally R18+) and was successful, the board noted the film depicted sexual violence as highly cruel and portrayed the characters in a demeaning manner. (It was rerated R18+ again in 2010)
{{Expand list|date=February 2015}}
==Members== The current permanent members of the Classification Review Board:<ref>[http://www.classification.gov.au/www/cob/classification.nsf/Page/ClassificationinAustralia_Whoweare_ClassificationBoard_ClassificationReviewBoardMembers Classification Review Board Members]</ref> *Victoria Rubensohn (Convenor) *Hon Trevor Griffin (Deputy Convenor) *Ann Stark *Helena Blundell *Alan Wu *Melissa de Zwart
==See also== {{Portal|Australia}} *[[Advertising Standards Bureau (Australia)]] *[[Australian Classification Board]] – A statutory censorship and classification body for Australia *[[List of banned films|Banned films]] – includes an extensive list of films banned in Australia *[[List of banned video games|Banned video games]] *[[Censorship in Australia]] *[[Internet censorship in Australia]] *[[Pornography by region|List of pornography laws by region]] – Australian hardcore pornography laws *[[Video game controversy]] – includes the history of games censorship in Australia
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox film | name = Bachelor Girl | image = | image size = | caption = | director = Rivka Hartman[http://www.balladfilms.com.au/Hartman.html Biography at Ballad Films] accessed 20 June 2013 | producer = Ned Lander | writer = Rivka Hartman | based on = | narrator = | starring = Lyn Pierse
[[Kim Gyngell]]
[[Bruce Spence]] | music = | cinematography = | editing = | studio = Yarra Bank Film Pty Ltd | distributor = ABC | released = 7 February 1988 | runtime = 83 mins | country = Australia | language = [[English language|English]] | budget = A$690,000"Production Survey", ''Cinema Papers'', May 1987 p77 | gross = | preceded by = | followed by = }} '''''Bachelor Girl''''' is a 1988 Australian TV movie.David Stratton, ''The Avocado Plantation: Boom and Bust in the Australian Film Industry'', Pan MacMillan, 1990 p331 ==Plot== Dorothy Bloom is a 32-year-old single soap opera writer planning a long, quiet weekend in Melbourne. Her Aunt Esther wants her to meet a gynecologist but instead she runs into Karl Stanton, an old friend from uni days. ==Cast== *Lyn Pierse as Dot Bloom *[[Kym Gyngell]] as Karl Stanton *Jan Friedl as Helen Carter *[[Bruce Spence]] as Alistair Dredge Jr *Doug Tremlett as Charles *Ruth Yaffe as Aunt Esther *Jack Perry as Uncle Isaac *[[Monica Maugham]] as Sybil *[[Tim Robertson]] as Grant *Mark Minchinton as Gazza *Christine Mahoney as Jenny *Denis Moore as Bert ==Production== It was financed with the assistance of Film Victoria and the Australian Film Commission.Scott Murray, ''Australia on the Small Screen 1970-1995'', Oxford Uni Press, 1996 p10 ==Reception== The TV critic from ''The Age'' called the film "wonderfully whimsical. A sort of Aussie ''[[Heartburn]]'', it combines liberal helpings of Jewish philosophy and humour, off-beat animation, accelerated footage and delicious satire."[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1300&dat=19880205&id=6L1YAAAAIBAJ&sjid=VukDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1953,2234651 Barbara Hooks, TV review ''The Age'' 5 February 1988 p 12] accessed 20 June 2013 ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0123397/ ''Bachelor Girl''] at [[IMDB]] *[http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/494351/Bachelor-Girl/ ''Bachelor Girl''] at [[TCMDB]] *[http://www.screenaustralia.gov.au/find-a-film/detail.aspx?tid=714 ''Bachelor Girl''] at [[Screen Australia]] [[Category:Australian films]] {{1980s-Australia-film-stub}}

revision.comment: Adding [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "Iraqi television channel" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|Iraqi television channel}} {{Infobox television channel | name = Altaleea TV
{{lang|ar|قناة بلادي الفضائية}} | logofile = | logosize = | logoalt = | logo2 = | launch = 2013 | picture format = | share = | share as of = | share source = | network = | owner = | slogan = | country = [[Iraq]] | language = [[English language|English]], [[Arabic]] | editor = | broadcast area = Worldwide, via [[Satellite television|satellite]] and [[internet]] | headquarters = [[Baghdad]], [[Iraq]] | former names = | replaced names = | sister names = | timeshift names = | web = {{url|http://www.beladitv.tv/}} | online serv 1 = Live stream | online chan 1 = {{url|http://www.beladitv.tv/live.php}} }} ''' Beladi TV''' ({{lang-ar|'''قناة بلادي الفضائية'''}}) is an [[Iraq]]i satellite television channel based in [[Baghdad]], [[Iraq]]. The channel was launched in 2013.{{cite web|url=https://www.sumeronline.com/tv/beladi-tv.html|website=sumeronline.com|title=tv/beladi-tv|accessdate=2018-10-05}}{{cite web|url=http://www.non14.net/45169/|title=مراسل قناة بلادي في كربلاء :الاجهزة الامنية منعتنا من دخول المستشفى ولقاء جرحى تفجير الحي الصناعي|website=non14.net|accessdate=2018-10-05}} Owned by [[Ibrahim al-Jaafari]]{{cite web|url=http://mowr.gov.iq/ar/node/819|title=تقرير قناة بلادي الفضائية حول الندوة العلمية لوزارة الموارد المائية | وزارة الموارد المائية|website=mowr.gov.iq|accessdate=2018-10-05}}{{cite web|url=https://www.ircs.org.iq/tag/قناة-بلادي-الفضائية/|title=قناة بلادي الفضائية | جمعية الهلال الاحمر العراقي|website=ircs.org.iq|accessdate=2018-10-05}}{{cite web|url=https://www.alghadpress.com/news/أخبار-العراق/57922/إصابة-مراسل-قناة-بلادي-بمعارك-الفلوجة|website=alghadpress.com|title=إصابة مراسل قناة "بلادي" بمعارك الفلوجة|accessdate=2018-10-05}}{{cite web|url=https://www.sotaliraq.com/2017/10/27/قناة-بلادي-نموذج-لحوارات-تخرج-عن-سياقا/|title=صوت العراق | قناة بلادي..نموذج لحوارات تخرج عن سياقات الحيادية والحرفية وأخلاقيات المهنة!!|website=sotaliraq.com|accessdate=2018-10-05}}{{cite web|url=https://www.iraqakhbar.com/138932|title=الداخلية: إخماد حريق بمولدتين أهليتين بالقرب من قناة بلادي الفضائية - اخبار العراق|website=iraqakhbar.com|accessdate=2018-10-05}} ==See also== {{Portal|Iraq|Media}} *[[Television in Iraq]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.beladitv.tv/ Beladi TV Official website] {{Iraqi broadcast television}} [[Category:Television stations in Iraq]] [[Category:Arab media]] [[Category:Arabic-language television stations]] [[Category:Television channels and stations established in 2013]] [[Category:Arab Spring and the media]] {{Iraq-stub}} {{tv-station-stub}}

[[File:2006-07-07 katze mit angel.jpg|thumb|Playing cat]] [[File:Cattoy.jpg|thumb|Cat chewing on a toy]] [[File:Cat and ball.jpg|thumb|Cat playing with ball]]
'''Cat play and toys''' incorporates predatory games of "play aggression". [[Cat]]s' behaviors when playing are similar to hunting behaviors. These activities allow kittens and younger cats to grow and acquire cognitive and [[motor skills]], and to [[socialize]] with other cats. Cat play behavior can be either solitary (with toys or other objects) or social (with animals and people). They can play with a multitude of toys ranging from strings, to small furry toys resembling what would be prey (e.g. mice), to plastic bags.<ref>ASPCA. Animal Behavior Center. "Play aggression".</ref><ref name="Tabor2003">{{cite book|author=Roger Tabor|title=Understanding Cat Behavior|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7-PDwgJHVS8C&pg=PA67|date=30 April 2003|publisher=David & Charles|isbn=0-7153-1589-7|page=75}}</ref>
== Defining object play == Object play for animals (in this case, cats) is the use of inanimate objects by the animal to express play behaviour. <ref name=":1">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?hl=en&lr=&id=jkiTQ8dIIHsC&oi=fnd&pg=PA45&dq=cat+play+behaviour+and+toys&ots=08zc2X7z7u&sig=KA3ewyI75AWt7asz0ZdeS9KcGTg#v=onepage&q=cat%20play%20behaviour%20and%20toys&f=false|title=Animal Play: Evolutionary, Comparative and Ecological Perspectives|last=Bekoff|first=Marc|last2=Byers|first2=John A.|date=1998-06-04|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9780521586566|language=en}}</ref> In the case of pet domestic cats, humans normally provide them with purchased, human-made toys such as toy mice. When it comes to non-domestic, wild cats, they may use several objects in the wilderness as their toys including sticks, leaves, rocks, feathers, etc. Actions that cats may carry out as this play behaviour include throwing the toy object, chasing, biting, capturing, etc. as they might do with a real source of prey. Engaging in object play helps young cats to practice these skills that they need as they grow into adults.<ref name=":1" />
==Nature of play==
=== Play in kittens === Play in cats is a behaviour that is brought about during growth from the kitten stage onward. Some important aspects of this play behaviour for the development of kittens in to adult cats include motor development, social behaviour and cognitive development. <ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Mendoza|first=Diana, L.|last2=Ramirez|first2=J. Martin|date=1987|title=Play in kittens (felis domesticus) and its association with cohesion and aggression|url=https://link.springer.com/content/pdf/10.3758%2FBF03330067.pdf|journal=Bulletin of the Psychonomic Society|volume=25 (1)|pages=27-30|via=Springer}}</ref>There are different types of play that develop at different stages during the development and growth of a kitten. The first play behaviours observed in kittens include things like approaching, pawing and holding onto each other. Following this stage in their development, kittens begin to show an interest in inanimate objects and prey behaviour. This is the development of their nonsocial behaviour in which they become more independent and begin to practice predatory/hunting behaviour. Play behaviour in kittens is also important in providing them with physical exercise as they are growing, as well as providing a means of interacting with other members of their litter to keep strong social bonds among them. <ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=West|first=Meredith|date=1974|title=Social play in the domestic cat|url=https://watermark.silverchair.com/14-1-427.pdf?token=AQECAHi208BE49Ooan9kkhW_Ercy7Dm3ZL_9Cf3qfKAc485ysgAAAiowggImBgkqhkiG9w0BBwagggIXMIICEwIBADCCAgwGCSqGSIb3DQEHATAeBglghkgBZQMEAS4wEQQMsVDNXzipXXmwpeLNAgEQgIIB3UakpGb4PwGuLER5eb3AfDS8oVddvKgZJcG2SfpEePTxhXQ3rUbDZ_4mn1XQkbZMBD5AAR9qUlujggP7sdJWQrrJ1xMAr7TZSu9_UD-9V_NkCWCQANMywWVlV4I44n7syYvCTtJgZcVkkW2S2578udMGqId88ZeKOFvGTKgmGSzUyVnE-LqdGcxsnem_1mtTL5ZQS9NMHiftNRi81zFwXJ8CG4MiMUxduxvo3sIQel2tSZuZcn_594bNZMkJdp9uGlzDHtxHSsHAdcWhIlkBugB8ozw3LvgxmTRzxU9ZsNrtsnci0_qnpvRSFuUOw5qLBmnSEJlPKH1o6YLf21AtZdfdhCGZv1qPso4CJh6755xEybPFzI2Iu23R2cYwwhGAYwg4vN4U_FDIpz38JzeI8VSMhL7IKFgwnG5gUEMW5DtShUaMbqN05kjRZUvAkBLzjzPHYFi5J82KPMWdvl_XRvzFASEfVTC8RT71YXVxgwEH8NjPoDaW7mupoqrHIEW5yzBV5Bdw4ZMMjbevwN9ghoqG9QcKDzNOPupn3sOKbvHERRhEO81pTNQZ-1AmmoVWtkXsqdEYeO8JXYhxJErocDcOLJutHln06D-tzw5SNPkX0cYrUKJcYLebJIYu0g|journal=American Zoology|volume=14|pages=427-436|via=}}</ref> Social play is important between litter-mates since this is the main source of play for kittens in early life with little alternative to other means of play. <ref name=":3" /> Kittens are limited in room for exploring for other means of play, so engaging in this social play behaviour is important until they have access to other play objects such as toys. <ref name=":3" />
===Predation=== [[File:Predatorycat ubt.jpeg|thumb|Predation]] Since cats are meat-eating [[Predation|predators]], nearly all cat games are predatory games.<ref>Hall & Bradshaw 1998.</ref>
[[Predation|Prey]] are fearful of predators. Predators often encounter prey that attempt to escape predation. Prey that move towards the cat with confidence may be exhibiting an aggressive defensive posture. Cats often play with [[toy]]s that behave more like fearful prey trying to escape than toys that mimic more confrontational prey.
===Success rate=== Success rate is important in play. A cat that catches its prey every time soon gets bored, and a cat that never gets it just loses interest. The ideal hunting success rate is around 1 in 3 to 1 in 6. Capturing prey at this rate generally maximises a cat's interest in the game.<ref>{{Citation | last = Bessant | first = Claire | title = The Complete Guide to the Cat | publisher = Barnes & Noble Publishing | year = 1999 | pages = | isbn = 0-7607-1718-4 }}</ref>
===Precautions=== Play is about predatory behaviour, and a highly excited cat can cause minor injuries in the excitement of the moment. With most cats, it is wise to keep playthings at least 20 cm (8") away from fingers or eyes and avoid encouraging a cat to eat inedible toys. If playing with a human's bare hands, a cat will generally resist using its claws or biting too hard, but a cat that becomes extremely excited may accidentally inflict injuries to its human playmate in the form of light scratches or small puncture wounds from biting too hard. Cats' claws and mouths can contain bacteria that can lead to infection, so it is wise to clean and treat any wounds with an antiseptic solution and seek professional medical services if there is reason to believe that the wound has become infected.
===Food=== Catching and [[eating]] are two closely related but separate activities. Domestic cats often store caught [[food]] for eating later. Eating happens when the game is over, so incorporating food into hunting games tends to end the interest in play. Hidden treats helps engage cat's senses such as sense of smell and can be a form of play which enables them to utilize their searching skills. This idea of treats linked with play helps cats form the association that treats signify happy behaviour.
== Defining motor aspects of play == There are several different motor patterns associated with the play behaviour of cats and they have different roles in the social context. <ref name=":02">{{Cite journal|last=West|first=Meredith|date=1974|title=Social play in the domestic cat|url=https://watermark.silverchair.com/14-1-427.pdf?token=AQECAHi208BE49Ooan9kkhW_Ercy7Dm3ZL_9Cf3qfKAc485ysgAAAiowggImBgkqhkiG9w0BBwagggIXMIICEwIBADCCAgwGCSqGSIb3DQEHATAeBglghkgBZQMEAS4wEQQMsVDNXzipXXmwpeLNAgEQgIIB3UakpGb4PwGuLER5eb3AfDS8oVddvKgZJcG2SfpEePTxhXQ3rUbDZ_4mn1XQkbZMBD5AAR9qUlujggP7sdJWQrrJ1xMAr7TZSu9_UD-9V_NkCWCQANMywWVlV4I44n7syYvCTtJgZcVkkW2S2578udMGqId88ZeKOFvGTKgmGSzUyVnE-LqdGcxsnem_1mtTL5ZQS9NMHiftNRi81zFwXJ8CG4MiMUxduxvo3sIQel2tSZuZcn_594bNZMkJdp9uGlzDHtxHSsHAdcWhIlkBugB8ozw3LvgxmTRzxU9ZsNrtsnci0_qnpvRSFuUOw5qLBmnSEJlPKH1o6YLf21AtZdfdhCGZv1qPso4CJh6755xEybPFzI2Iu23R2cYwwhGAYwg4vN4U_FDIpz38JzeI8VSMhL7IKFgwnG5gUEMW5DtShUaMbqN05kjRZUvAkBLzjzPHYFi5J82KPMWdvl_XRvzFASEfVTC8RT71YXVxgwEH8NjPoDaW7mupoqrHIEW5yzBV5Bdw4ZMMjbevwN9ghoqG9QcKDzNOPupn3sOKbvHERRhEO81pTNQZ-1AmmoVWtkXsqdEYeO8JXYhxJErocDcOLJutHln06D-tzw5SNPkX0cYrUKJcYLebJIYu0g|journal=American Zoology|volume=14|pages=427-436|via=}}</ref>Pouncing is one of these motor patterns in which it is used to initiate play through physical contact. Chasing and horizontal leaping is an example of a motor pattern that may be used by a cat to end play. The movement of a cat's tail during play and the varying rates at which the cat may move its tail can even be a useful indicator of its level of playfulness. There are patterns of belly-up and stand-up actions that are engaged in by kittens in which seem to show that they prefer to engage in physical contact play in terms of their social role among other kittens.<ref name=":02" />
== Influence of hunger on cat behaviour == Hunger has been shown to give an increase in intensity in the play behaviour of cats, and a decrease in fear which they show towards larger-sized toys. <ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://www-sciencedirect-com.qe2a-proxy.mun.ca/science/article/pii/S0168159197001366|title=Memorial University Libraries - Proxy Login|website=www-sciencedirect-com.qe2a-proxy.mun.ca|access-date=2018-10-29}}</ref> This effect that hunger has on play behaviour may be attributed to how experienced of a hunter the cat is. It is not expected that a cat who has a higher level of hunting experience would show this increased intensity of their play behaviour when hungry. Instead, they are more likely to show more predatory behaviour. In the case of cats with a lower level of hunting experience, they show this increased play behaviour since they are not able to engage in actual predatory activities and instead show predatory behaviours towards toys when hungry as an experienced hunter would show towards actual prey when hungry.<ref name=":2" />

{{for|the British TV series|OK! TV}} {{Infobox television | show_name = Celebrity Page | image = | genre = [[Infotainment|Entertainment and celebrity]]/[[News magazine]] | presenter = {{Plainlist| *[[Sonia Isabelle]] *Jaymes Vaughan * }} | country = United States | language = English | num_seasons = 5 | executive_producer = {{Plainlist| * Mark Berryhill * James Lisi }} | runtime = 22 to 24 minutes | company = {{Plainlist| * Unconventional Partners * }} | distributor = [[Trifecta Entertainment & Media]] | channel = {{Plainlist| * [[Broadcast syndication|Syndication]] * [[Reelz]] }} | picture_format = [[480i]] ([[standard definition television|SDTV]])
[[1080i]] ([[high definition television|HDTV]]) | first_aired = {{Start date|2013|9|9}} | last_aired = present | website = https://www.celebritypage.com/ }} '''''Celebrity Page''''' (formerly '''''OK!TV''''', that is based on the [[OK!|magazine of the same name]]) is an American [[Broadcast syndication|syndicated]] entertainment news program. The series is being co-produced by [[Meredith Corporation]] (formerly ''OK!'' US parent company [[American Media (publisher)|American Media]]), Unconventional Partners, and [[Trifecta Entertainment & Media]].[http://www.americanmediainc.com/ok-magazine-launch-fall-2013-syndicated-tv-strip-ok-tv "OK! Magazine to Launch Fall 2013 Syndicated TV Strip OK! TV 2012"] press release from American Media (October 18, 2012) The series premiered on September 9, 2013.[http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/492067-Exclusive_Trifecta_s_OK_TV_a_Firm_Go_for_Fall_2013.php "Exclusive: Trifecta's 'OK! TV' a Firm Go for Fall 2013"] from Broadcasting & Cable (February 27, 2013) It is also broadcast several times daily on the cable network [[Reelz]], which is a production partner in the program.{{cite news | url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news/2013/09/04/reelzchannel-partners-with-ok-tv-71205/20130904reelz01/ | title=ReelzChannel Partners with OK! TV | work=The Futon Critic | date=September 4, 2013 | accessdate=October 22, 2013}} On March 15, 2016, Trifecta announced that the series would be renamed ''Celebrity Page'' as a result of changing its partnership from [[American Media (publisher)|American Media's]] ''OK!'' magazine to [[Meredith Corporation]], which returned to producing content for syndication ten months after the [[Better (TV series)|''Better Show'']] was canceled. The change took effect on March 28, 2016.[http://www.tvnewscheck.com/article/93128/meredith-partners-on-syndicated-magazine "Meredith Partners On Syndicated Magazine,"] from ''TVNewsCheck'', 3/15/2016 ==Details== The series focuses on pop culture, celebrity news, gossip and lifestyle stories, some sourced through Meredith's television stations and magazine resources (though not those of the former [[Time Inc.]], including ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' and ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''; Meredith completed their purchase of Time Inc. in January 2018, but those magazines have their own platforms and content agreements), along with ''[[Soap Opera Digest]]''. The program is co-hosted by [[Sonia Isabelle]] in [[New York City|New York]] and Jaymes Vaughan in [[Los Angeles]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{U.S. tabloid television shows}} [[Category:2010s American television series]] [[Category:2013 American television series debuts]] [[Category:American television series based on British television series]] [[Category:First-run syndicated television programs in the United States]] [[Category:English-language television programs]] [[Category:Entertainment news shows]] [[Category:Infotainment]] [[Category:Meredith Corporation]] [[Category:Reelz television series]]
